title: Over 2 million Yemen children are starving
text: Share 62 shares In Sana'a, some Yemenis have been unpaid since President Abedrabbo Mansour Hadi decided in September to move the central bank out of the city and into his government's temporary capital of Aden. The move has left the rebels, who have set up their own administration in Sana'a, unable to pay the salaries of public sector employees. 'The number of child beggars has surged, mainly after salaries stopped for government employees in the capital,' said Ahmed al-Qurashi, head of Seyaj, a Yemeni organisation for the protection of children. On the pavements of the capital, scores of children sit waiting for cars to stop at traffic lights. Less than a third of the country's population has access to medical care, and less than half of health of facilities are functional A young child with severe malnutrition cries in Yemen, where humanitarian groups are facing a huge crisis Less than a third of the country’s population has access to medical care, and less than half of health facilities are functional 'We have nothing to eat or drink,' eight-year-old Raghad told people as she begged for help. UNICEF said the situation is worst in Sada'a, Hodeida, Taizz, Hajjah and Lahej. In Sana'a, eight out of 10 children are chronically malnourished. But less than a third of the country’s population has access to medical care, and less than half of health facilities are functional. Health workers have not been paid their wages for months and aid agencies are struggling to bring in lifesaving supplies because of the political deadlock between the warring parties. UNICEF said a shortage of funding is hindering efforts which can address the crisis, with £56million needed to provide nutrition services to mothers and children across the country.
